title: Nicolas Cachanosky Director | Center for Free Enterprise   The University of Texas at El Paso
text:
CV
  
  
    
     
  
  
    
     
  
  
    
     
  

  
  


I’m an Associate Professor of Economics and the Director of the Center for Free Enterprise at The University of Texas at El Paso. I’m also a Senior Fellow at the American Institute for Economic Research nd a Fellow at the UCEMA Friedman-Hayek Center for the Study of a Free Society.
Along with João P. Bastos, I’m the editor of Public Choice in Latin America. I also serve as an Associate Editor of the Southern Economic Journal. Previously, I was president of the Association of Private Enterprise Education (APEE) and a director of The Mont Pelerin Society (MPS).
This website shares information about my research, and I regularly blog at Economic Order about economic policy and research.

title: Nicolas Cachanosky Director | Center for Free Enterprise   The University of Texas at El Paso
text:
I’m an Associate Professor of Economics and the Director of the Center for Free Enterprise at The University of Texas at El Paso. I’m also a Senior Fellow at the American Institute for Economic Research nd a Fellow at the UCEMA Friedman-Hayek Center for the Study of a Free Society.
Along with João P. Bastos, I’m the editor of Public Choice in Latin America. I also serve as an Associate Editor of the Southern Economic Journal. Previously, I was president of the Association of Private Enterprise Education (APEE) and a director of The Mont Pelerin Society (MPS).
This website shares information about my research, and I regularly blog at Economic Order about economic policy and research.

title: Milei
section: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
Nicolas Cachanosky
UTEP Center for Free Enterprise
Woody L. Hunt College of Business

title: Milei
text: The New Rise of Populism

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
The Context

2001: The Argentine Great Depression
What did the median voter learn from the 2001 crisis?

Neo-liberal reforms do not work
Free market policies are highly corrupt
Economic growth takes place at the expense of blue-collar workers and low-income households
International organizations and financial institutions are bad actors
The government must “do something”

Perfect setting for the rise of a new populist regime

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Economic Freedom Index in Argentina

Economic Freedom declining under populism, slight improvement under Cambiemos
Populism period shows dramatic decline in economic freedom
Cambiemos showed modest improvement
Argentina consistently ranked among the least economically free countries

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Economic Stagnation: 13 Years and Counting

Monthly Economic Activity (Dec 2015 = 100)
Major contractions:

-12.5% (2001 crisis)
-11.0% (2009 global crisis)

-23.8% (2020 pandemic)

13 years of stagnation from 2011-2024

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Inflation: A Persistent Problem

Average inflation since 1945: 62%
Multiple hyperinflationary episodes
Recent acceleration with question mark for 2024 projections
Chronic monetary instability

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
What Explains Milei’s Rise?

The Cambiemos coalition failed (after yet another currency crisis)
Milei is an outsider who speaks against the political caste (more relevant than free-market rhetoric)
A lost young population looking for new hope (be it libertarian or Marxist)
Milei is not the only right-wing outsider who reacts to the pink tide

Trump, Bolsonaro, Meloni, Vox, Piñera…

Lucky win?

The Kirchnerismo inflated his campaign to crowd out votes from Cambiemos
Milei adopted Cambiemos’ omnibus law and staff

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
section: Milei’s Economic Plan and the Two Mileis
text: Milei’s Economic Plan and the Two Mileis

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Electoral Support Analysis
Electoral Support: 55% of Votes

Strong support (30%): For Milei
Weak support (25%): Against Kirchnerismo

Two paths considered: - ❌ Permanent monetary reform (dollarization) - Path not taken - ✅ Transitory monetary reform (Caputo’s plan) - Path taken

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
The Caputo Plan - Phase 1

Depreciate the exchange rate (from 400ARS/USD to 800ARS/USD)
Set a crawling peg of 2% (monthly)
Cut spending
Move short and mid-term central bank liabilities to the Treasury
Facilitate disbursement of new financial aid and transition to new monetary regime including lifting capital controls

Two anchors: 1. Monetary (stop “printing money”) 2. Fiscal balance

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
The Monetary Anchor
Inflation is going down, why?

Two temporary shocks to inflation:

Massa’s plan platita
Devaluation in December 2023 (roughly from 400 to 800 pesos per US dollar)

Price controls (health insurance, utility providers, grocery stores)

Future inflation concerns: - What is happening to money supply? - What will happen to the Treasury budget?

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Monthly Inflation Trends

Kirchnerismo period: High volatility, average around 8-12%
Mileismo period: Initial spike to 25.5%, then declining trend
Plan platita + exchange rate depreciation caused the spike
Recent months showing decline to around 3.5-4.2%

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Monetary Base Expansion

“Look, since we arrived [to the government], the monetary base practically shows no change […]. As a result, the monetary base does not change. Today we have zero net reserves and the same monetary base. This is the anchor, the anchor is the quantity of money.”
— Milei, Llao Llao, April 19, 2024

Reality: Accumulated expansion continued to 148% by November 2024

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
section: The Monetary Anchor Was the First Casualty
text:
The Monetary Anchor Was the First Casualty
Accumulated Change in Currency in Circulation (%)

Continued expansion throughout 2024
Reached 119.5% by November 2024
Contradicts claims about monetary stability

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
The Fiscal Anchor
Government Spending Cuts (Cash-flow based, in real terms): - Private sector: 48% - Public sector: 52%
How the “surplus” was achieved: - Postpone payments (don’t pay your bills) - Default and unilateral debt restructuration with the energy sector - Pension and social programs real cuts - Accrued results show a different story

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Fiscal Sustainability Concerns
Is this balanced budget credible?

Government may “relax” cuts to social programs if political cost becomes too high
Congress may impose fiscal costs:

Block tax raises
Mandate pension adjustments
Government under-adjusted January payments

Milei has no political power in Congress, no governors, no mayors…
The 2% crawling peg is not sustainable
Can the government handle a new depreciation?

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
The Caputo Plan - Phase 2

Use central bank reserves to maintain the crawling peg for the long-term
Open statement against the IMF
Fewer reserves being accumulated at the central bank
Capital controls to remain for the foreseeable future
Enough USD to pay debt obligations?
Freeze broad base money

Broad base money: Base money + central bank short-term liabilities

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Institutional Concerns
Positive: - More young population curious about free-market ideas - Political debate focused on what matters: Regulatory inefficiency and unsustainable deficits
Negative: - More rejection of free-market ideas, now seen as an ideological fanatical movement instead of scientific and philosophical doctrine - Increased polarization and division among the Argentine free-market movement

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
Who’s Actually in Government?
Milei’s political party, La Libertad Avanza (LLA) is allegedly a libertarian party, but…

Who is NOT in the government?

Free-market economists (at least not in relevant positions)

Who IS in the government?

[The presentation shows photos of what appear to be traditional political figures]

Political populism is not about economic policy, it is about political behavior

title: Can Milei Reform Argentina Back to Prosperity?
text:
The Dangerous Strategy: Liberalism = Milei
If Milei deviates from free market principles, or if his government fails…

Free-market policies will be seen as a failure once put in practice
“You see… once in power libertarians are just like any other politician”

Evidence of deviation: - Price controls - Nepotism - Failed policies - Disrespect for institutional constraints - Appoint corrupt judges to the Supreme Court (and not even a constitutionalist one) - Double standards (Milei can criticize anyone, but he should not be criticized)
Question: Will Argentine libertarians be able to say that “Milei did not truly represent them” after so much enthusiastic endorsement?
